closing
commenting

we need a way to checkpoint these files also.. Shall we implement a simple filesystem modified time based tailing, with checkpoints stored on hdfs ? or leave it to the end user? (This could be too much to handle for naive user)

Should we just have JDBCRDD or a SQL data frame with a sql wth ts > clause to simulate the sqoop workflow? I guess do we want this a utility for getting started guide or a more generic utility thats productionazible in future.

@prazanna Not sure if that route will have as mature support for datatypes as SQOOP has.. I'd vote for sticking with SQOOP and having something people can get up & running in production quickly for atleast 1 target use-case
@vinothchandar Okay, lets see if setting up a sqoop job and saving it as incremental deltas is something we can do for showcasing a use-case.
@vinothchandar - FYI for review

Current HoodieBloomIndex is built to handle joining of arbitrary number of incoming records to partitions and adapt to skews nicely..

eg: if we had 200M records, each 500 bytes going into a partitionPath with 100 files, a naive join would result in > 2GB size records per partition (each file is a partition say)

Most of this implementation relies on sorting to achieve this & loads the bloom filter lazily for each file. As a result, simply caching an RDD in this piece of code is not straightforward.

I am going to rethink the problem with different tradeoff and implement a new HoodieCachedIndex

Our flow typically is

    index.tagLocation (this should use the in-memory file => bf map to do tagging)
    table.upsert() (actual write, after which we know new file => bf mapping and also updates to existing bf
    index.updateLocation (this reflects the above changes onto index)

Using mapWithState is problematic for the following reasons

    Step 1 & 3 above if done as two separate mapWithState operations, will end up having its own hashmaps. i.e you ll look up one hashmap and update another.
    there is no way to use MapWithStateDStream:: stateSnapshots() to read it again each micro batch. This is because, it effectively becomes a circular dependency and thats not a thing in Spark

Off to exploring ways, to implement an RDD ourselves to do the caching. This is not straightforward.

Think about supporting multiple delta files - on compaction failures
    Fall back of on-disk merge if the delta file size exceeds certain limit
For example Index, storage/table type etc..

The following is the gist of changes done

1. All low-level operation of creating a commit code was in HoodieClient which made it hard to share code if there was a compaction commit.
2. HoodieTableMetadata contained a mix of metadata and filtering files. (Also few operations required FileSystem to be passed in because those were called from TaskExecutors and others had FileSystem as a global variable). Since merge-on-read requires a lot of that code, but will have to change slightly on how it operates on the metadata and how it filters the files. The two set of operation are split into HoodieTableMetaClient and TableFileSystemView. 
3. Everything (active commits, archived commits, cleaner log, save point log and in future delta and compaction commits) in HoodieTableMetaClient is a HoodieTimeline. Timeline is a series of instants, which has an in-built concept of inflight and completed commit markers. 
4. A timeline can be queries for ranges, contains and also use to create new datapoint (create a new commit etc). Commit (and all the above metadata) creation/deletion is streamlined in a timeline
5. Multiple timelines can be merged into a single timeline, giving us an audit timeline to whatever happened in a hoodie dataset. This also helps with https://github.com/uber/hoodie/issues/55. 
6. Move to java 8 and introduce java 8 succinct syntax in refactored code

Upon deep introspection of the Spark 2.x code line, it seems like the changes ought to be in 

- CatalogFileIndex.scala 

Need more clarity.

Ideas around this 
- Having a list of all file ids within each partition path
- Having query engines filter the versions, based on commit metadata

Few options discussed here.

There are 3 problems
- Recover from a partially written log
- Atomically publish a delta commit
- Handle duplicates in log when spark retries on failure

Thoughts
- A Delta commit can have metadata about the FileId, delta version, offset and writes all the records of that commit in a block. 
- From a list of commits and FileID, we can get the list of delta files and offset and can load the delta records in memory in parallel
- This gives us a way to atomically publish all data in a commit and will never read data that is not committed (for failures) and we can continue appending to a corrupted avro file (if it allows or move to a next version - need to check on this)

- MapFile has the index to records, and if this can be a MapFile instead of a avro file, the index will be available in the delta file. Need to investigate this feasibility as well.
Related issue: https://github.com/uber/hoodie/issues/59
fixes #58
LGTM

Perfect. Thanks.

This is possible when insert parallelism is too small or when there are lot of error during insert (most likely) and 1 or more RDD[WriteStatus] serialized all the error records and it became more than 2 GB and this is a fundamental limit on the block size of a RDD. https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SPARK-1476.

Workaround would be to increase the parallelism when doing the collect() in HoodieWriteClient.commit() (https://github.com/uber/hoodie/blob/master/hoodie-client/src/main/java/com/uber/hoodie/HoodieWriteClient.java#L313)
#22 Resolves this as part of the refactor

There are broadly three approaches we can take here. 

### Approach 1 : Setting Path filters 

Only works on Spark 2.x, we have to do something like below. 

`spark.sparkContext.hadoopConfiguration.setClass("mapreduce.input.pathFilter.class", classOf[com.uber.hoodie.hadoop.HoodieROTablePathFilter], classOf[org.apache.hadoop.fs.PathFilter]);`

Tested basic counts, and a three-way join. Seems to work. 

### Approach 2 : Make spark also work with  `@useFileSplitsFromInputFormat`

This is doable, and would probably ensure a smoother path forward. To do this, we need to change `PartitionAwareFileIndex`, to call ipf.getSplits based on the annotation.. Doable, but needs some munging of interfaces. Better done, with direct feedback from Spark community,  

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SPARK-19351

For now, will get Approach 1, ready, so we have 1 more option in the bag. Will add unit tests around joins etc.. 

  @prazanna how is our path towards Spark 2.0 looking?

Your abstraction thinks of this a OO exercise and makes sense. But there are some practical limitations to consider.

We need transfer objects which can be serialized (HoodieLogFile and HoodieFile) are those objects. HoodieLogAppender will be task executor specific. Also dont think the concept of rolling log is not specific to HoodieDeltaLog (thinking this will be re-used in archivedlog and in global index in future). TrimLog and compact log can be methods in RollingAvroLogAppender. We could still have HoodieAvroLogFile, HoodieCommitLogFile  extending from RollingAvroLogAppender.

Lets discuss this on a separate issue, once the code for MoR is in, the abstraction changes will be more concrete.

Okay Now I see what you mean. We can have "log" abstractions over the reader and writer which unifies getting a reader and writer from a single log interface. Lets add this later. I will create a issue to track it.
yep. we could auto tune this too, but having more parallelislm in commit does not hurt.

yeah I think we are saying the same things. Overall for Hoodie as project, we need a File abstraction, and a log abstraction that builds on top of it and provides the functionality of the RollingLogAppender and the Composite Log reader ... 

lol.. I am thinking how that in itself will be an useful OSS project :)
Overall, go ahead merge this, once you ahve the follow on commit with the few things we are fixing. Created #68 to follow up on other thigns discussed here
@prazanna  merging this, so you can see this under `concepts` link
Feel free to merge, after you look at the comments..

merge

Hanjun

I spent some time fleshing this out and here 's what I propose to redesign this and turn it into a very useful utility, that can ingest a kafka topic/sqoop output (Sqoop incremental import, basically writes .avro files onto hdfs . ), flume output whatever.. 

We generalize three concepts 

-  Sources : (Code to read a source and checkpoint it to keep doing it incrementally) 
    - HDFS : Files uploaded under a root directory , checkpointed by file upload time
    - Kafka : Messages written into a topic continuously, checkpointed by partition/offset
    - Hive : Output from HiveIncrementalPuller as supported today, checkpointed by hoodie commit time

-  Payload : (Code to interpret data in source, and turn it into HoodieRecord) 
    - JSON : Json data turned into HoodieRecord/Payload 
    - Avro : Avro data 
    - User can provide their own Payload class using --jars spark option if needed. We will do heatpipe in this fashion for Uber 

- SchemaProvider: (Entity providing Schema for a given table & also may be schema for reading data?) 
    - FileProvider :  As of today, file backed schemas
    - Could have other implementation => Schema service at Uber and Confluent Schema Service elsewhere 


This then just becomes a Spark utility you schedule via your favourite workflow engine.

We (@ Shopify) would be very much interested in that too. Right now we have a custom SQOOP-like extractor with some custom logic built-in, but we'd love to streamline the process to the point that extraction/integration is a simple utility.

Sounds good then.. 

We have a few folks at Uber who are looking to tee their writes to Cassandra/ElasticSearch into a Kafka topic and make it available on Hadoop. Looks like doing this right, will alleviate a lot of issues..

I plan to work on this over the weekend.. 

@dterror Would this be directly usable at Shopify? I ll add you to the PR, so you can suggest edits

Here's my proposed changes.. 

a) Have the HoodieIOHandle write a `.hoodie_meta` file in each partition path, with the base path for that hoodie dataset
    - Will take care of partial writes, concurrent writes etc 
b) Modify HoodieInputFormat and HoodieROTableFilter to first look for meta file, then fall back to current logic if not found
c) Will add a utility to CLI, to write this metadata out to table partitions if it is not found. 
   - We can use this to repair the current datasets and eventually deprecate the fallback logic from classes above.
d) Will add unit tests..
@prazanna cool with ths?

Yes, it is usable, (just not immediately usable), but would definitely love
being added. Thanks @vinothchandar

General steps
1. Read existing data and upsert into target hoodie dataset (if the source parquet files does not have duplicates - then this copy can be avoided - may be have a flag for this)
 a. If no data copy - then rename the files, read and compute write back files with bloom filters
 b. If it involves data copy - then re-use much of the upsert path
2. Create a backfill commit.

This is how the cli options look now.. Lets the user drop their own implementations for 
 -  `Source` => HDFS, Kafka, another Hoodie table
-  `SchemaProvider` => Default just read from a file. We can integrate Confluent registry as follow task
- `Payload`  => Default just overwrites the table with value from Source. But user can do soemthing custom 
- `KeyExtractor` => How do extract the `HoodieKey` from record.

```
Usage: <main class> [options]
   Options:
     --help, -h
        Default: false
     --hoodie-client-config
        path to properties file on localfs or dfs, with hoodie client config.
        Sane defaultsare used, but recommend use to provide basic things like metrics
        endpoints, hive configs etc
    --key-extractor-class
        Subclass of com.uber.hoodie.utilities.common.KeyExtractor to generatea
        HoodieKey from the given avro record. Built in: FieldNameBasedKeyExtractor (Uses
        provided field names as recordkey & partitionpath. Nested fields specified via dot
        notation, e.g: a.b.c)
        Default: _uuid
    --key-extractor-config
        Path to properties file on localfs or dfs, with KeyExtractor configs. For
        list of acceptable properites, refer the KeyExtractor class
     --max-input-bytes
        Maximum number of bytes to read from source. Default: 1TB
        Default: 1099511627776
     --op
        Takes one of these values : UPSERT (default), INSERT (use when input is
        purely new data/inserts to gain speed)
        Default: UPSERT
        Possible Values: [UPSERT, INSERT]
     --payload-class
        subclass of HoodieRecordPayload, that works off a GenericRecord. Default:
        SourceWrapperPayload. Implement your own, if you want to do something other than overwriting
        existing value
        Default: com.uber.hoodie.utilities.deltastreamer.DeltaStreamerAvroPayload
    --schemaprovider-class
        subclass of com.uber.hoodie.utilities.common.SchemaProvider to attach
        schemas to input & target table data, built in options: FilebasedSchemaProvider
    --schemaprovider-config
        path to properties file on localfs or dfs, with schema configs. For list
        of acceptable properties, refer the schema provider class
     --source-class
        subclass of com.uber.hoodie.utilities.sources.Source to use to read data.
        built-in options: com.uber.hoodie.utilities.common.{DFSSource (default),
        KafkaSource, HiveIncrPullSource}
        Default: com.uber.hoodie.utilities.sources.DFSSource
    --source-config
        path to properties file on localfs or dfs, with source configs. For list
        of acceptable properites, refer the source class
     --source-format
        Format of data in source, JSON (default), Avro. All source data is
        converted to Avro using the provided schema in any case
        Default: JSON
        Possible Values: [AVRO, JSON, ROW]
     --source-ordering-field
        Field within source record to decide how to break ties between  records
        with same key in input data. Default: 'ts' holding unix timestamp of record
        Default: ts
     --target-base-path
        base path for the target hoodie dataset
    --targetTable
        name of the target table in Hive
```

Source checkpoints (where we are on the source stream) are stored as a part of commit. Exactly-once FTW!!

Hey Jan,

Thanks for bringing this up. Sorry about the oversight. We will most certainly change the project name. The name (Hoodie) was an extension of HUDI - Hadoop Upsert anD Incrementals. 

In 3 days, we have a [strata talk](https://conferences.oreilly.com/strata/strata-ca/public/schedule/detail/56511) , where we are talking about Hoodie. We may not be able to change the name everywhere before then, but we will change it soon after and also mention about the name change in the talk (to avoid any confusion). 

Hope this does not concur a lot of inconvenience to the hood.ie project. Btw, tried out the quickstart and I think its awesome. Good luck with your project. Will update the this ticket once, we change the name reference in all places. 

Cheers
Prasanna

Best

task1 - was opening bloom filter for about 200 files and reading the entire file contents for ~50 files
task2 - was opening bloom filter for 1 file.

This is not trivial to repartition based on just files. We cannot exceed 2GB in the remote shuffle block after join (ProbableFileId1, RowKey), which is why we auto size and split the partitions (files * records / num_of_elements_that_can_fit_in_2GB) that way. 
Lets call this number as computed_parallelism.

Also there are 2 skew in this discussion,
1. Skew in the number of files to check in the final joined partition
2. Skew in the runtime of each partition
Even if 1 is resolved, we cannot guarantee that we can eliminate 2. The actual work may skew and we cant do anything to solve that. So in any case, we are trying to do an estimate on the work to be done in each partition.

To solve 1:
Introduce indexParallelism (new property) and over provision indexParallelism. The index parallelism will be max(inputRDD.partitionsize, indexparallelism, computed_parallelism).
With over-provisioning, We may have multiple tasks opening up the same file, but the skew should be handled. computed_parallelism will be a cover in case index parallelism may hit the 2GB limit.

We make modifications on how we compute computed_parallelism. We can limit a partition to only read a configurable limit of files (maxIndexFileLookup) and create subpartitions based on that limit. PR referred does this.

Hey @HenryCaiHaiying,

Thanks for the question. 

Answer to that question is we store the commit time in the record that is saved. So when you set the mode to be incremental, the appropriate parquet file versions are picked by the input format (https://github.com/uber/hoodie/blob/master/hoodie-hadoop-mr/src/main/java/com/uber/hoodie/hadoop/HoodieInputFormat.java#L104) and using a predicate  _hoodie_commit_time > startTs and _hoodie_commit_time < endTs (which is pushed down when reading the parquet file), we get only the records that changed during that time period.

https://uber.github.io/hoodie/quickstart.html#incremental-queries - this has an example you can try from hive. 

PS: Today, Incremental pull is only supported from the compacted parquet files. Supporting avro files is under development and should be available soon. 

Let us know if you need more clarifications
Prasanna

Yes, once bloom filter test passes, we ensure that the key is actually in the parquet file. Columnar access of a single field is usually very effective in parquet. Bloom filter false positive rate is configured by default as 0.000000001 (very low).

-Prasanna
Thanks, very helpful answer.

Note that this fp rate is much much lower than what is used in LSM based key value stores, if you are thinking about that.. 

Just wondering, do you have a potential use for hoodie?
It should be, although have not tried it.. Merge on read, in general is under active development, so we can definitely make this work as needed..

Ah secor :) . We used that for a while at uber too. Its hard to integrate with Secor, in general we moved away from Secor & High level consumer, since it could not scale to 1000s of kafka topics we have..

Anyways, I encourage you to take a look at `HoodieDeltaStreamer` which achieves similar exactly once ingestion.. Another issue for you could be dealing with S3 & eventual consistency.. We are trying to setup a time with amazon folks to go over that..

For #2, it depends on the amount of files in each partition, as you put it..  the subpartitioning will explode the bigger partitions into multiple subpartitions to try handle it.. 

Coming back to #1, 

`task1 - was opening bloom filter for about 200 files and reading the entire file contents for ~50 files`

do we know the time split between reading the bloom filter for 200 files vs reading contents of ~50 files.. If so, can we dig into why the fp rate is as high as 1/4? Generally speaking, reading bloom filter takes few ms and looking at logs, checking a file takes ~1 sec. So yes, you may see 200 sec vs 1 sec for few tasks.. But the point still remains as to what in the workload or HDFS performance affects this equation.. 

A custom partitioner can be written to bound the amount of IO per read - but needs more thought and given the cost of copy-on-write is dominated by actual file IO, not sure about ROI here.
Are you able to deploy master?  Does this fix need to be backported to a 0.2.X release for uber's deploy?

And also 
 
- df.write.format('hoodie').save() should work seamlessly
Here we hope to have support for faster, point lookup (batch)
test comment

Thanks for suggesting this feature.  Sounds like a good thing to add for folks doing pySpark etc ..  I will think a little about file structure for housing python files and report back. 

At a high level, this sounds a lot like `HoodieReadClient`, it might be worthwhile to see if the logic from the class can be invoked by python? (same way pySpark calls the jvm RDD classes to get its stuff done)..  This would lead to the filtering code maintained in 1 place, 1 language, thus easier to maintain? thoughts?

@prazanna and I did a brainstorm, to see if cleaning async should cause issues. I think it should be fine.. Just in case, think through any more corner cases at a conceptual level, before we go ahead to impl?

I would prefer just adding a new config using which we can provide parallelism for this stage if needed. This would avoid any surprises like rereading same file multiple times like vinoth mentioned. That way, we do not have to test this feature with all datasets again. This issue will get fixed once we have global indexing anyway and we are hitting this issue only with one dataset for now, no point over-optimizing this till then.
